headline: Nigeria expecting 3.92million COVID-19 vaccine doses July
summarized_story:
The Federal Government on Tuesday said it was expecting a shipment of 3.92 million doses of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine by the end of July or early August.
The Executive Director, National Primary Healthcare Development Agency, Dr Faisal Shuaib, disclosed this at a press conference in Abuja.
He said, “We now have information that Nigeria will get 3.92 million doses of Oxford/Astrazeneca by the end of July or early August.
He added, “It is therefore comforting to know that the vaccine used in Nigeria can protect against this variant that causes high morbidity and mortality in India.

headline: LIGHT UP YOUR LIVING ROOM WITH INTIMATE LIGHTINGS
summarized_story:
Natural Light: If you’re blessed with a South-facing space, you’re going to need a lot less light for the daytime and perhaps won’t need to consider as much task lighting.
To create a more intimate atmosphere, bring lighting to a lower level via table lamps and short floor lamps.
Mood and Task Lighting: Extra task and mood lighting is often where design schemes fall short.
Homeowners assume that the central light or wall lights are enough at full power, instead of thinking about the layering effect.
Light Up the Candles: Candles are the last piece of the puzzle when creating a relaxing and intimate atmosphere.

headline: Factional Nigerian Students Association President, Asefon, Aides Risk Jail Terms For Abusing Naira Notes
summarized_story:
The factional President of the National Association of Nigerian Students (NANS), Sunday Asefon and some of his aides have violated the Central Bank of Nigeria’s rule, which forbids anyone from abusing the naira by spraying and stepping on them in public.
In a video obtained by SaharaReporters, Asefon was seen being sprayed wads of cash at an event while he stepped on them.
Sunday AsefonSome students have expressed their reservations about the 19-second clip, calling on the Nigerian government to sanction Asefon.
Some based their complaints on financial waste and others on disregard for the Central Bank of Nigeria’s (CBN) regulation against spraying or stepping on the naira.
According to Section 21(3) of CBN Act 2007 “spraying of, dancing or matching on the Naira or any note issued by the Bank (CBN) during social occasions or otherwise howsoever shall constitute an abuse and defacing of the Naira or such note and shall be punishable under Sub-section 1 of this section.”The law, in Section 5 (i) goes further to define “Matching” to include “spreading, scattering or littering of any surface with any Naira notes or coins and stepping thereon, regardless of the value, volume, occasion or intent” while in 5(ii) “Spraying” includes adorning, decorating or spraying anything or any person or any part of any person or the person of another with Naira notes or coins or sprinkling or sticking of Naira notes or coins in a similar manner regardless of the amount, occasion or the intent.”WATCH: NANS President, Asefon, Aides Publicly Violate CBN Act Days After Receiving N70m From Nigerian Government, Yahaya Bello pic.twitter.com/TQLwL97eCb — Sahara Reporters (@SaharaReporters) June 15, 2021In Section 21(4), it is also a punishable offence for “any person to hawk, sell or otherwise trade in the Naira notes, coins or any other note issued by the Bank.”The stated offences above are punishable under Sub-section 21(1) which provides, among other things that, a person “shall on conviction be liable to imprisonment for a term not less than six months or to a fine not less than N50,000 or to both such fine and imprisonment.”

headline: Ethio Telecom 40% stake sale set to break up Ethiopia’s enduring telecoms monopoly
summarized_story:
Ethiopia has announced a tender process for the sale of a 40% stake in state-owned telecommunications company, Ethio Telecom.
The proposed minority sale of Ethio Telecom – the sole mobile services provider in a country of over 100 million people – is part of a broader plan to liberalise the country’s monopolistic telecoms sector.
In May, the government awarded one of the two available private operating licences to break up Ethio Telecom’s monopoly on the sector.
According to Brook Taye, a senior advisor at the finance ministry, the 40% in Ethio Telecom will be sold as a single stake to a single investor.
Founded in November 2010, Ethio Telecom currently has around 53 million subscribers and has since December generated a revenue of around $600 million.

The program of activities for the election will begin with the publication of the Notice of Election on February 1, 2022, according to a timetable issued by INEC Secretary Rose Oriaran-Anthony on July 10, 2021.

headline: Niger gov’s angst on 150 kid-captives: Bandits’ informants in my government
summarized_story:
Politicians within government corridors have been releasing strategic planning to bandits as informants in order to make money, Governor Abubakar Sani-Bello of Niger state has said.
Even when we hold meetings, few moments later, the bandits will be saying the governor has said this and that.
He expressed concern that some people were eager to make money while children within ages three and 11years were in captivity.
Zakiri was known for leading other vigilantes in protecting his community and environs against invaders that killed and destroyed properties.
Governor Bello Mohammed Matawalle had last week, directed communities across the state to go on self-defence whenever bandits strike.

headline: JUSUN commends Ita Enang for support during industrial action -NigPilot
summarized_story:
Judicial Staff Union of Nigeria, JUSUN, has commended the Secretary, Presidential Implementation Committee for Autonomy of State Judiciary and Legislature, Senator Ita Enang, for his support during the period of their industrial action to press home their demands for a free, strong and independent judiciary in Nigeria.
“The above mention Union write to appreciate your support during the period of her industrial action to press home her demands for free, strong and independent Judiciary in Nigeria.
“The Union believes that if judiciary became free, the justice system would be better administered for the betterment of Nigerians.
“While thanking you for your continuous support during and after the turbulent time of our great union, we assure you of our support always,” part of the letter read.
Senator Enang is also the Senior Special Assistant to the President on Niger Delta Affairs.

headline: Ita Enang urges State Govs to engage youths on insecurity -NigPilot
summarized_story:
Senior Special Assistant to the President on Niger Delta, Senator Ita Enang, has called on State Governors to engage youths in their states to find ways of addressing the security challenges confronting the country.
“We need to apologies to them and on my little part I apologies to them for the little we did not do at certain time and please let return back to the table.
He added that “when we were busy educating our children in the best of schools, what did we do for them, when we were busy thinking of the welfare of our children.
“So we are collectively reaping the fruit of bad governance at the state level while President Buhari is now saddled with the responsibility to finding solution to the problem.
By God grace he is providing the solution,” he added.

headline: Christian Aid advocates for domestication of Child Rights Act -NigPilot
summarized_story:
An international non-governmental organization – Christian Aid Nigeria and other Civil Society Organisations (CSO) are advocating for the domestication of the Child Rights Act as part of activities lined up to commemorate the 2021 International Day of the African Child.
The group identified religious and cultural beliefs as the major factors militating against full domestication of the Child Rights Act in most national and sub-national authorities across Africa.
This is contained in opinions expressed during a Webinar organised by Christian Aid UK, Nigeria to discuss Child Rights.
Mr Martins Abantlehe, Programme Communications Volunteer, Christian Aid said that the International Day of the African Child was designated by the African Union on June 16th yearly to draw attention to the plights of the African child.
He further explained that in Nigeria, the Child Rights Act is the policy framework that exists to provide and protect the rights of a Nigerian child; and other related matters.

headline: F.G blames Twitter for losses during #EndSARS -NigPilot
summarized_story:
The minister stressed that it was unfair to conclude that the operation of Twitter was suspended indefinitely because it deleted President Muhammadu Buhari’s message.
“If you ask people to donate money via bitcoins for EndSARS protesters then you are vicariously liable for whatever is the outcome of the protest.
Mohammed said among other conditions for Twitter to resume operation in Nigeria, there must be an agreement as to what contents it could post.
“I can confirm that Twitter has written the Federal Government that they are ready to talk.
As we have always maintained, the door is not locked and we are open-minded but Twitter must work towards it,” he said.

headline: FG Reopens First Dose COVID-19 Vaccination, Says Second Dose To End June 25
summarized_story:
The Nigerian government has reopened the administration of the first dose of the Oxford/AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in various parts of the country.
Shuaib called on all Nigerians who have received their first dose to check their vaccination cards for the date of their first dose.
He asked them to ensure that they receive the second dose between six and 12 weeks from the date they took the first dose, to gain full protection against the COVID-19 virus.
The NPHCDA boss stated that in some cases, the location of the second dose could be different from that of the first dose.
“I, therefore, urge all Nigerians who have received their first dose at least six weeks ago to visit the nearest vaccination site to receive their second dose, for full protection against COVID-19 on or before June 25 when we shall close the administration of the second dose,” he pleaded.

headline: Nigeria’s Headline Inflation Drops To 17.93%, But Food Prices Rise
summarized_story:
Nigeria’s headline inflation dropped for the second consecutive month in May, but the prices of food have continued to surge.
While this is 0.19 per cent points lower than the 18.12 per cent recorded in April, increases were recorded in all Classification of Individual Consumption by Purpose (COICOP) divisions that yielded the headline index.
Similarly, the urban inflation rate rose to 18.51 percent (year-on-year) in May from 18.68 per cent recorded in April, just as the rural inflation rate stood at 17.36 per cent in May from the 17.57 per cent previously reported.
Food Prices On The RiseThe composite food index, on the other hand, rose by 22.28 per cent in May as against the 22.72 per cent reported in April.
It disclosed that the food sub-index increased by 1.05 per cent in May from the 0.99 per cent recorded in April, on a month-on-month basis.

headline: Reps Screen Chief Of Army Staff
summarized_story:
The House Of Representatives Joint Committees on Army and Defence has screened President Muhammadu Buhari’s nominee for the position of Chief of Army Staff, Major General Farouk Yahaya.
The screening took place on Tuesday behind closed doors in the National Assembly chambers in Abuja.
Speaking earlier, Major General Farouk Yahaya in his introductory remarks, stated that contrary to public perception, there has been synergy among security agencies to tackle insurgency, especially since the emergence of the new service chiefs.
Read Also: Army Releases New Postings, Appointments Of Senior OfficersPresident Buhari appointed Major General Yahaya as the new Chief of Army Staff on May 27.
The appointment came days after the immediate past army chief, Lieutenant-General Ibrahim Attahiru died in an air crash in Kaduna along with 10 other military officials.

headline: We Will Tame The Monster Of Corruption In Nigeria – EFCC Boss
summarized_story:
Chairman of the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) Abdulrasheed Bawa says he is optimistic that the anti-graft agency will tame the monster of corruption in the country.
Bawa said this on Tuesday during an interview on Channels Television breakfast programme, Sunrise Daily, when he was asked if the scope of corruption overwhelms him.
No, because I am very optimistic we will succeed in taming the monster of corruption in this country.
“We have already designed the manual for that.”Forty-year-old Bawa was appointed EFCC Boss by President Muhammadu Buhari on February 16.
During his screening by the Senate, Bawa vowed that the constitution will guide his actions as the EFCC Chairman.

headline: At Least Three Judges Sit In Lagos As Courts Resume Activities
summarized_story:
At least three judges of the Lagos High Court in Ikeja sat to hear proceedings on Tuesday following the resumption of judicial activities in courts across the country.
Court staff, lawyers, and litigants arrived at the court premises, some as early as 8am while most of the courtrooms were open with parties seen moving in and out.
This was because the dates for hearings had been overtaken by the industrial action by members of the Judiciary Staff Union of Nigeria (JUSUN).
Elsewhere at the Federal High Court in Ikoyi, activities were on low-key with only one judge sitting when the crew monitored proceedings.
JUSUN embarked on a nationwide strike on April 6 to demand the implementation of the financial autonomy of the judiciary.

headline: Governor Uzodinma charges Policemen to take the fight to bandits, Others
summarized_story:
Imo State Governor Hope Uzodimma has told the police not to close their eyes and allow bandits to murder them in cold blood.
The governor charged the officers and men to shoot the bandits first before they are killed.
AdvertisementHe also charged the officers to up their game in tackling insecurity and restoring peace and stability in the state.
With the support of the Governor, we have done our best to restore normalcy and peace in the state.
We shall continue to do our best to maintain a safe state for citizens and residents of Imo State,” Yaro said.

headline: BREAKING: APC National leader, Bola Tinubu returns from overseas trip
summarized_story:
The national leader of the All Progressives Congress, Asiwaju Bola Ahmed Tinubu, has returned to Nigeria from his overseas trip.
The former Lagos state governor arrived in the country at about 7pm local time.

headline: Nasarawa Government Invokes No Work, No Pay Rule as industrial action continues
summarized_story:
The Nasarawa State government has invoked the no-work-no-pay rule for striking civil servants in the state.
This is part of the resolutions taken at an emergency expanded security meeting held at the Government House, Lafia.
The emergency meeting was convened at the instance of Governor Abdullahi Sule, which is aimed at seeking for amicable resolution of the plight of the striking workers.
The state government expressed dismay over the indefinite strike action embarked upon by the organised labour.
It directed permanent secretaries at the various ministries, departments and agencies, to open attendance registers in order to actualise the no-work-no-pay rule.

headline: Euro 2020: Ronaldo Makes History with 11th Goal as Portugal Thrash Hungary
summarized_story:
Europeans champions Portugal kicked off their Euro 2020 title defence with a 3-0 win over Hungary on Tuesday as captain Cristiano Ronaldo made history at the Puskas Arena.
Borussia Dortmund’s Raphael Guerreiro broke the deadlock after 84 minutes with a shot from the centre of the box, while Ronaldo scored from a penalty three minutes later.
Amid a backdrop of around 60,000 fans at the Puskas Arena, Hungary held firm in a low-key first half that had little incident.
Boosted by vociferous support at the Puskas Arena, Hungary threatened sporadically, with Adam Szalai causing Portugal the most problems.
First Guerreiro broke the deadlock with a deflected finish, before Ronaldo took centre stage.

headline: Fresh Covid-19 Spike in Rwanda as Government Mulls Lockdown
summarized_story:
Rwanda is experiencing a sharp rise in Covid-19 cases and deaths despite ongoing vaccination efforts days after President Paul Kagame warned there could be a “new lockdown”.
The country’s health ministry is reporting that new infections have risen exponentially in the last seven days.
Nearly 390,000 people have so far been vaccinated – and most of those have had their second jabs.
Health Minister Daniel Ngamije says nearly five million more vaccines are expected and more have been ordered.
“Our target is to reach 7.8 million people vaccinated early next year,” he told the state broadcaster.

headline: Seven Million Nigerians Pushed Below Poverty Line in 2020, World Bank
summarized_story:
About seven million Nigerians have been pushed below the poverty line in 2020 due to the rapid rise in prices of commodities.
The international financial institution said food prices accounted for over 60% of the total increase in inflation, with the rise in prices severely impacting Nigerian households.
The bank stated this in a press statement titled, “Critical reforms needed to reduce inflation and accelerate the recovery, says new World Bank report,” and released by the World Bank’s Senior External Affairs Officer of Nigeria, Mansir Nasir.
“Although the economy started to grow again, prices are increasing rapidly, severely impacting Nigerian households.
Rising prices have pushed an estimated 7 million Nigerians below the poverty line in 2020 alone.”The World Bank Country Director for Nigeria, Shubham Chaudhuri was quoted to have noted that “Nigeria faces interlinked challenges in relation to inflation, limited job opportunities, and insecurity.

headline: Mozambique on High Alert Over Growing Covid-19 Cases
summarized_story:
Mozambique is on high alert as the country continues to witness an increase in the number of Covid-19 cases.
The Southern Africa country’s health ministry says cases had gone down from March till May but in the last 14 days, has recorded 773 new cases against 442 cases in the same period last month.
Meanwhile, the second phase of the country’s vaccination campaign has started with the aim of vaccinating 23,000 people, including teachers, over the next two weeks.
“In this second phase, the second dose will be administered to those who have already taken the first dose and the first dose to the new groups,” Dr Matsinhe said.
The health ministry has already immunised around 350,000 people – and intends to eventually vaccinate a total of 16 million people.

headline: Zambia’s Founding President Kaunda Admitted to Hospital
summarized_story:
Zambia’s founding president Kenneth Kaunda has been admitted to a hospital in the country’s capital, Lusaka for pneumonia, a close aide has said.
A statement from his office says the 97-year old Kaunda has asked for prayers for his recovery.
He was addressing rumours that Mr Kaunda had coronavirus.
Mr Kaunda is said to be improving.
There has been growing concern about his health especially as Zambian President Edgar Lungu, along with South Africa’s leader Cyril Ramaphosa, had asked people to pray for Mr Kaunda.
